Just going through PA questions for the first time, and I find so many absurd questions. Cramming what model supports what version?? Common!
You also don't have to cram specific location of all config item to know how to administer a device. Otherwise, how many devices in this day and age will you master?

questions.question_text:
An engineer decides to use Panorama to upgrade devices to PAN-OS 10.2.

Which three platforms support PAN-OS 10.2? (Choose three.)

choices.C: Only when log at session end is enabled

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

comments.content: Why would you want to log a deny policy at session start? It will just consume FW resources
For deny rules, you log them at session start only, not session end.

discussion.content: It could be "B", cause if you want to log a Deny policy you need to set Log at session start checkbox, but A is more accurate with the best practices. So it could be both but A is more accurated for question context.

A. Logging at session start is usually used when troubleshooting applications that don't change over the course of the session, or applications that aren't recognized by the firewall. https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000Clt5CAC

Selected Answer: A
https://knowledgebase.paloaltonetworks.com/KCSArticleDetail?id=kA10g000000Clt5CAC#:~:text=Logging%20at%20session%20start%20is,on%20the%20management%20plane's%20CPU.

Selected Answer: A
A
temporary when troubleshooting

questions.question_text: As a best practice, logging at session start should be used in which case?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Depending on the type of log you want to use for tagging, create a log forwarding profile or configure the log settings to define how you want the firewall or Panorama to handle logs.

 For Authentication, Data, Threat, Traffic, Tunnel Inspection, URL, and WildFire logs, create a log forwarding profile.
 For User-ID, GlobalProtect, and IP-Tag logs, configure the log settings.
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/policy/use-auto-tagging-to-automate-security-actions

Yes, should be C.
User-ID log is management plane log, so its forwarding profile should be set up at "Device\Log settings".

For Authentication, Data, Threat, Traffic, Tunnel Inspection, URL, and WildFire logs, create a log forwarding profile.
For User-ID, GlobalProtect, and IP-Tag logs, configure the log settings.

Correct answer C
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/policy/use-auto-tagging-to-automate-security-actionsa

I read the question again and it says apply tags to used ID logs. 

Log setting is correct answer

Selected Answer: B
Correct answer is B 
Log Forwarding is required to forward the logs with tagging on.

Selected Answer: C
There is no option for udser-id in log forwarding settings. Log settings (Device tab) has a User-ID section

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
On the 1/23/24 exam

C. Depending on the type of log you want to use for tagging, create a log forwarding profile or configure the log settings to define how you want the firewall or Panorama to handle logs. https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/9-1/pan-os-admin/policy/use-auto-tagging-to-automate-security-actions

questions.question_text: What must be configured to apply tags automatically to User-ID logs?

The profile is configured to provide granular defense against targeted flood attacks for specific critical systems that are accessed by users from the internet.

Which profile is the engineer configuring?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Verbiage matches exactly to a KB:
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/zone-protection-and-dos-protection/zone-defense/dos-protection-profiles-and-policy-rules

Selected Answer: B
B: (DDoS) the ask was to protect a specific critical system
D( Zone ) Yes, it offers flood protection but for the Zone


DDoS:
Configure a DoS Protection profile for flood protection
For Flood Protection, select all types of flood protection:
SYN Flood
UDP Flood
ICMP Flood
ICMPv6 Flood
Other IP Flood
------
A Zone Protection profile with flood protection configured defends 
an entire ingress zone against SYN, ICMP, ICMPv6, UDP, and other IP flood attacks

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
DoS Protection profiles and DoS Protection policy rules combine to protect specific groups of critical resources and individual critical resources against session floods. Compared to Zone Protection profiles, which protect entire zones from flood attacks, DoS protection provides granular defense for specific systems, especially critical systems that users access from the internet and are often attack targets, such as web servers and database servers

Selected Answer: B
I think its B because it's for a specific system 

https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-2/pan-os-admin/zone-protection-and-dos-protection/zone-defense/dos-protection-profiles-and-policy-rules.

DoS Protection profiles and DoS Protection policy rules combine to protect specific groups of critical resources and individual critical resources against session floods.

Compared to Zone Protection profiles, which protect entire zones from flood attacks, DoS protection provides granular defense for specific systems, especially critical systems that users access from the internet and are often attack targets, such as web servers and database servers.
